title: 110_hr998
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Civil Rights History Project Act of 2008". Congress finds that individuals should stand up for their rights and beliefs, as demonstrated by the actions of those who participated in the Civil Rights movement. The movement had visible leaders like Thurgood Marshall, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., and Rosa Parks, but also many others whose impact was equally important. The Civil Rights movement participants hold valuable first-hand memories that should be recorded for future generations to learn from. A Federal project to collect oral histories would provide a detailed history of this important period and serve as a model for similar projects in the future. The purpose of this Act is to create a federally sponsored project to collect video and audio recordings of personal histories from individuals who participated in the American Civil Rights movement. The Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution will preserve and make these oral histories available to the public, serving as models for future projects in museums, libraries, and universities nationwide. The Act aims to support documentary work on the American Civil Rights movement by collecting personal histories to preserve the memories of individuals involved, allowing future generations to appreciate their sacrifices. Establishment of joint project at Library of Congress and National Museum of African American History and Culture to collect video and audio recordings of histories of participants in American Civil Rights Movement. The Librarian of Congress and the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution will establish an oral history project to survey collections of audio and video recordings of Civil Rights movement participants. The Librarian of Congress and the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution will establish an oral history project to collect video and audio recordings, as well as written materials, related to the personal histories of individuals who participated in the Civil Rights movement. The project aims to create a collection of these materials, catalog and index them, and make them available for public use through the Library of Congress and the National Museum. The Secretary, through the Director of the National Museum of African American History and Culture, will carry out duties under the Act. The Librarian and the Secretary may collaborate with other entities through agreements and partnerships to collect and make available recordings related to the project. The Librarian and the Secretary may procure services, accept volunteer help, and make advance payments to collect video and audio recordings under the Act. They will begin collecting materials as soon as possible after the enactment of the Act. The Librarian and the Secretary will collect audio recordings and materials related to the Civil Rights movement, focusing on the period 1954 through 1968. The term "Civil Rights movement" refers to the movement for racial equality in the United States for African Americans, challenging racial segregation and achieving equal rights legislation for all citizens. SEC. 4. PRIVATE SUPPORT FOR CIVIL RIGHTS HISTORY PROJECT.

The Librarian of Congress and the Secretary are encouraged to solicit and accept donations to support activities related to the Civil Rights movement. Donated funds will be dedicated solely to these activities.

SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $500,000 for fiscal year 2009 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2010 through 2013.
